rule: The output must consist of exactly four non-empty lines in the fixed order: Company names, People names, Specific topics, General themes.
input: Acme Corp invited Elena Ruiz to review quarterly earnings for Q2. The memo also referenced long-term business strategy and market positioning.
validityText:
The input is a plain natural-language text string containing arbitrary prose (a memo invite), including company and person names, a quarter reference, and business topics. It fits within the specification’s allowance for any length, content, punctuation, and special characters without requiring any specific structure.

OK
coverageText:
Company names: Acme Corp
People names: Elena Ruiz
Specific topics: quarterly earnings for Q2, long-term business strategy, market positioning
General themes: financial reporting, strategic planning, market analysis
coverageEvalText:
Output uses correct fields and format as specified.
OK

rule: Each of the four lines must begin with the exact label followed by a colon and a single space, using the exact capitalization and spelling: "Company names: ", "People names: ", "Specific topics: ", and "General themes: ".
input: Globex and Northwind Traders held a joint briefing. Miguel Santos and Dr. Priya Shah debated supply chain delays and pricing strategy within international trade and retail operations.
validityText:
The input is a single natural-language text string containing arbitrary written content with company names, person names, and discussion topics. This fully complies with the specification, which allows any prose of any length, in any language, with any characters. 
OK
coverageText:
Company names: Globex, Northwind Traders
People names: Miguel Santos, Dr. Priya Shah
Specific topics: supply chain delays, pricing strategy
General themes: supply chain management, pricing, global commerce, retail
coverageEvalText:
Output follows required four categories and formatting.
OK

rule: After the colon and space on each line, the content must be a comma-separated list of items where items are separated by a comma followed by a single space, with no trailing comma at the end of the line.
input: Product managers at ByteWorks coordinated with Contoso and GreenLeaf Organics. Aisha Khan, Jordan Lee, and Omar Patel discussed feature rollout, bug triage, and user onboarding to support software development and product management.
validityText:
The input is a plain natural-language text string with company names, person names, and discussion topics. It fits the specification allowing arbitrary prose, punctuation, and names, with no structural requirements beyond being text. 
OK
coverageText:
Company names: ByteWorks, Contoso, GreenLeaf Organics
People names: Aisha Khan, Jordan Lee, Omar Patel
Specific topics: feature rollout, bug triage, user onboarding
General themes: software development, product management
coverageEvalText:
Format is correct with all required sections and comma-separated lists.
OK

rule: Items in the lists must not contain commas themselves, because commas are reserved exclusively as separators between items in the lists.
input: Stellar Labs filed a new patent. Naomi Park prepared the application for a patent filing to strengthen the company’s intellectual property.
validityText:
The input is a plain-text natural language passage consisting of two sentences. It contains company and person names, standard punctuation, and no prohibited structure. This fully complies with the specification, which allows arbitrary prose of any length, in any language, including names and punctuation.  
OK
coverageText:
Company names: Stellar Labs
People names: Naomi Park
Specific topics: new patent, patent filing
General themes: intellectual property protection, patent law
coverageEvalText:
Format and labels match the specified entity extraction structure.
OK

rule: Each item in any list must be a concise phrase and must not be a complete sentence, and no item may end with a period, question mark, or exclamation mark.

I reviewed the input and it is a single natural-language text string of arbitrary content, containing names, plans, and ordinary punctuation, without requiring any special structure beyond plain text. It fully complies with the specification.  
OK

People names: Carlos Mendes
Specific topics: reducing churn, customer retention, loyalty program design, writing long slogans
General themes: banking strategy, customer loyalty
coverageEvalText:
Format and labels follow the prescribed structure for entities and themes.  
OK

rule: No line may contain any text other than the required label, colon, single space, and the comma-separated list of items; the output must contain no explanations, headings, extra commentary, or echoed input text.

rule: People names are names of individual human persons mentioned in the input text, and each listed person name must match a person mention from the input text and may include honorifics or titles (e.g., Mr., Ms., Dr., Prof.) only if they appear with the name in the input text.
input: EduVerse partnered with local colleges. Prof. Maria Silva and Mr. John Okoro reviewed curriculum design to modernize higher education.

rule: Specific topics are concrete, narrowly scoped subjects discussed in the input text, expressed as short noun phrases typically one to four words long, and must not include proper names of companies or people.
input: At DevForge, Hana Mori proposed unit testing, continuous integration, and code review standards. The initiative advances software engineering practices.
validityText:
The input is a plain natural-language text string describing a proposal at DevForge. It contains person and company names, punctuation, and standard prose. This fully aligns with the specification allowing any arbitrary text, including names and punctuation, with no required structure beyond being plain text.

People names: Hana Mori
Specific topics: unit testing, continuous integration, code review standards
General themes: software engineering practices
coverageEvalText:

OK

rule: General themes are broad, overarching subject areas that summarize the content of the input text at a higher level of abstraction than the specific topics, expressed as short noun phrases typically one to five words long, and must not include proper names of companies or people.
input: MediPulse’s field team, led by Dr. Ahmed Salim, audited vaccine cold storage in clinics. The report connects tactics to public health and healthcare policy.

People names: Dr. Ahmed Salim
Specific topics: vaccine cold storage audit
General themes: public health, healthcare policy
coverageEvalText:
